newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo naphtha prices hit lowest level in 6 months.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo naphtha prices hit lowest level in 6 months.

text.p: Tokyo naphtha prices nosedived to a six-month low in afternoon trade on Monday due to planned naphtha cracker turnarounds in South Korea in May, arbitrage cargoes from the West as well as bearish crudes, traders said.
"It's a reaction to Western cargoes coming and Korean shutdowns, plus weaker crudes," one naphtha trader said.
Open-spec naphtha for the prompt trading period, which now is first-half June, was quoted at $208.00/209.50 per tonne, the lowest since early October.
It was assessed at about $213.00/214.50 in late dealing on Friday.
Second-half June was indicated a scant 50 cents lower than than the first-half June level. On Friday, one second-half June cargo was traded at $215.00 and another one at $214.00.
Naphtha prices have been sliding constantly since mid-March in line with crudes, after having shot up by more than 30 percent in the second half of 1996.
Traders expected prompt naphtha cargoes to find a bottom soon, and not to fall below the $200 level because the arbitrage window from Europe is currently closed.
In spreads, the backwardation was squeezed further, with first-half June/first-half July discussed at 50 cents/$1.50
